review.title: Issues in evaluating semantic spaces using word analogies
review.abstract: The offset method for solving word analogies has become a standard evaluation tool for vector-space semantic models: it is considered desirable for a space to represent semantic relations as consistent vector offsets. We show that the method's reliance on cosine similarity conflates offset consistency with largely irrelevant neighborhood structure, and propose simple baselines that should be used to improve the utility of the method in vector space evaluation.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Vector-space models of semantics (VSMs) represent words as dots in a high-dimensional space (Turney and Pantel, 2010). There is considerable interest in evaluating VSMs without having to embed them in a full NLP system. Such an intrinsic evaluation strategy, which has gained popularity in recent years, uses the offset approach to solving word analogy problems (Levy and Goldberg, 2014; Mikolov et al., 2013a; Turney, 2012). This method assesses whether a linguistic relationship - for example, between the base and the rounded form of a verb (debugging and debugging) - is consistently encoded as a specific linear offset in space. sections.heading: 3 Experimental setup
sections.text: Analogy problems: We use the analogy data set proposed by Mikolov et al. (2013a). This data set, which has become a standard VSM valuation set (Baroni et al., 2014; Faruqui et al., 2015; Schnabel et al., 2015; Zhai et al., 2016), contains 14 categories; see Table 1 for a complete list. A number of these categories, sometimes referred to as "syntactic," test whether the structure of space captures simple morphological relationships, such as the relationship between the base and the linear form of a verb (screaming: screaming). Others evaluate the knowledge that space encodes the world, e.g. the relationship between a country and its currency (latvia: latvia latvia). A last category that does not fit neatly into one of these groups is the relationship between the base and the linear form of a verb (screaming: screaming). Others evaluate the knowledge that space encodes the world via latvia, e.g. the relationship between a country: and its currency: via latvia).

sections.heading: 4 Results
sections.text: In line with Levy and Goldberg (2014), there was a slight advantage for MULTIPLY over ADD (mean difference in accuracy: 0.03), as well as dramatic variability in various categories (from.13 to.90 in ADD). This variability crosses the difference between world knowledge and morphological categories; performance in currencies and adjectives-to-adverbs was poor, while performance was high in capitals and comparatives. Although ADD and MULTIPLY always outperformed accuracy in baselines, the margin differed in the various categories. The most striking case is the plural category in which the accuracy of ONLY-B. 70, and even ADD-OPPOSITE achieved reasonable accuracy (.45).

sections.heading: 5 Discussion
sections.text: The success of the offset method in solving word analogy problems was assumed to indicate that systematic relationships between words in space are represented as consistent vector offsets (Mikolov et al., 2013c).The current note examined potential difficulties with this interpretation, but a literal ("vanilla") implementation of the method did not accomplish the task: the nearest neighbor of an economy − a + b was almost always b or an economy. Even if these candidates were excluded, part of the success of the analogy could also be achieved by baselines ignoring one or even both and an economy. Finally, reversing the direction of the analogy significantly impaired accuracy, even if the same offset was involved in both directions. Baseline performance varied far beyond analogy categories. Baseline performance was poor in the adjective-to-superlative relationship and was very high in the plural category.
